title: 103_s1249
content: The Act titled "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993" is cited as the short title. Between 10,000,000 and 15,000,000 people in the United States have been infected with tuberculosis, with nearly 26,000 new cases reported annually and over 1,700 deaths each year. The number of reported cases has increased from 22,201 in 1985 to 26,673 in 1992. Drug-resistant tuberculosis strains can be costly to treat, with a high mortality rate despite treatment. In 1992, cases were reported in all 50 states, with drug-resistant cases in at least 36 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In 1992, 27 percent of tuberculosis cases were in foreign-born persons, and one third of the world's population carries tuberculosis. Tuberculosis remains the top infectious disease killer globally, with 8,000,000 new cases and 2,900,000 deaths annually. SEC. 3. PROGRAMS OF CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act includes increased funding for tuberculosis prevention and control services, with a focus on high-risk populations and areas with high infection rates. States applying for grants must submit a plan outlining how the funds will be used to provide tuberculosis services effectively. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act includes increased funding for tuberculosis prevention and control services, with a focus on high-risk populations and areas with high infection rates. States must submit a plan demonstrating the use of grant funds for observed therapy or effective interventions. Additionally, the Secretary may conduct research and training to support these grants. The Public Health Service Act amendment authorizes increased funding of $26,000,000 for tuberculosis prevention and control from 1994 to 1997. A technical amendment removes a sentence from Section 317(j)(2) of the Act. The Public Health Service Act amendment authorizes increased funding for tuberculosis prevention and control. Research and research training regarding tuberculosis will be conducted through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. The Public Health Service Act authorizes increased funding for tuberculosis research through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, with $46,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 1994 and additional funding for subsequent years. The Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act is amended to include a new section for tuberculosis drug and device research. The Commissioner of Food and Drugs will implement a program to assist in developing tuberculosis protocols, review medical devices for tuberculosis diagnosis, and conduct research on drugs and devices for tuberculosis prevention. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for this purpose.
